Definition: It is expected that you will classify the comment into two classes: disagree and agree. classify the comment as disagree if it expresses strong disagreement. classify the comment as agree if there is no strong disagreement.

Comment: A lot of Europeans live the same way as Mr. Reguly describes.   Not all, to be sure, however, there are many.   

The one thing that needs to happen here to make more frequent grocery shopping feasible is for there to be either more high-quality small foodstores or small markets, especially in the summer.   The markets in Europe are amazing in a lot of places and it's possible to completely avoid large shops if you really want to in many places.

And I didn't grow up with air conditioning at all.   There was none in the house.   It's pretty tough in the city at times now without it, however, I sometimes wonder what would happen to urban temperatures if we really cut back our use of it and looked for other approaches to cooling.   Between concrete, glass, mirrors and air conditioning units, cities are heat mills in the summer now.

Comment: Just before the 1929 crash Joe Kennedy sold all his stocks when he started to get stock advice from the shoe-shine boy on the corner. What does that have to do with Amazon? Simply this: When the "experienced" generation - that includes me and my favourite columnist - start to use Amazon, the company is scraping the bottom of the barrel. We are the last holdouts who still shop "the old-fashioned way". They have already netted the yuppies and internet-savvy youngsters and are mopping up the last few disbelievers - the "shoe-shiners".
But with a price-earnings multiple of 180.7 today, the company is on shaky ground. It would take 180.7 years to recover your investment with Amazon at today's earnings. This is almost twice the level at which the Japanese stock market collapsed over twenty years ago. 
Yes, this is what the dot.com bubble felt like. Massive valuations and no earnings. I love ordering from Amazon. But the empire may be built on quicksand. I wouldn't bet money in this game.

Comment: The suggestions in this article are constructive ones, however, they will, sadly, fail for a lot of people if one important factor is not addressed,..the possibility of one or more significant nutritional deficiencies.

Addressing deficiency means the body is not crying out for nutrition and seeking what it lacks however it can.   There is a condition called pica which is a specific form of this condition typically related to iron deficiency.   Also, a lot of women crave certain foods during pregnancy they would not otherwise want to eat.   

I'm not sure why medical science accepts nutritional deficiency as the basis for medical conditions in these specific cases (pica, pregnancy related cravings), and rejects it as a possible contributor to overeating and weight gain.   The only conclusion I can draw is there is not enough profit in it.

Comment: What a tough one for Bounds and J.C.       On the one hand it was the result of bad luck and bad planning, and on the other a serious loss to local agriculture.  Here in the fabled Willamette Valley,  excellent farmland is too often lost to more lucrative development.  While we urbanites benefit from   the strict restriction on field burning of straw, it's one more problem for farmers struggling to make it.  Still, that seems a weak excuse for why that straw was left in such a position of  potential danger.  Fortunately local firefighters kept it  from being even worse.    This should  remind us all of the risks with fire, as a small  accidental fire ended up causing a massive devastation.

And it was massive-- these photos, with only  one from Friday night, don't do the scene justice.  We saw the red glow in the sky, and went to observe it for several hours.  Just incredible, the most widespread fire damage I'd witnessed personally since the Roseburg blast of August 1959.

Comment: SVHD does not strive to be all things to all people, rather it plays to its strengths as a rural hospital serving local needs. That means leaving costly services such as childbirth, surgery and ICUs to larger hospitals while focusing on certain high demand,  high value services including it's highly acclaimed Swing Bed program. To say Emergency Services provide “limited care” I believe does a disservice to both the ER and local residents who one day may experience a medical emergency. 

SVH is now seeking to partner/merge with a larger healthcare organization. Thanks to the new hospital building coupled with its reputation for medical excellence, it appears SVHD will be negotiating from a position of strength. 

There will be a Public Hearing about the Affiliation RFP on May 30th at 6:00pm at Snoqualmie City Hall. If ever there was a time to be informed, to get involved and to participate, it is now. 

Hope to see you then and there.

Scott Scowcroft, Seattle
www.bit.ly/svhforum

Comment: This is incomplete analysis. 

Overheads can be estimated for each specialization by region with a little research.

Compensation affects the capacity of - any - profession to deliver quality of service.

Dental offices can do X-rays, anaesthesia, sutures, day surgery etc.

Family physicians refuse to suture, will not set simple fractures, and do not have any X-ray facility. 

Therefore, patients overload ERs for routine cases causing long wait times.

The other major problem with the Canadian system is that most professionals have to go through 4 years of wasteful undergrad, rather than being accepted directly from high school into an integrated Co-op program.

Extra undergrad contributes to student uncertainty, increases student debt, decreases working years, and makes no contribution to the skill of the practitioner.

Comment: We considered recently to add a smallish sun room to our house - which was built about 60 years ago, plus renovations. Single family, rural - really no issues re: zoning, environmental, neighours ( none ), no easements, nada .....

We looked into the bureaucracy:
- Septic system inspection to ensure there was sufficient capacity in case someone "lived" in the sun room. 
- We are about 20ft. elevation above a small creek and pond. Would have had to get local conservation authority to inspect that we would not be flooded. The creek rises maybe 2 ft. during spring run-off.
- Plans and construction ( trivial ) would have had to undergo a complete building inspection, approval of plans, and ongoing construction supervision.
- The whole project would have had to go to "Toronto" to get a variance - I have no clue why.

At this point we gave up as the whole bureaucracy alone would have cost us more than the actual sun porch !!!

Comment: Sister Ilia writes beautifully of  the man Thomas Merton and his journey of openness to ever deeper levels of prayer. It is so sad that there are still people today who want to paint Merton as a heretic or some sort of person at odds with the teachings of the church.  Richard Rohr, OFM, whom I see as a modern day Merton, speaks so clearly about our inability to believe we are loved unconditionally by God, and therefore set up all sorts of limitations to God's grace, believing ourselves to be somehow  unworthy of God's love or thinking we have to earn it.
The last of my cancer patients, to whom I have been ministering, went joyously Home to the Kingdom's Feast, and it was my privilege to be with them as their journeys ended.  God is good, all the time...all the time, God is good.

Comment: I am familiar with this bomb. The MOAB is and has been available to theater commanders for several years and does not require Presidential approval. Trump has been honest in not saying he called for its use-- he did not. The commander did. Commanders have not used the bomb because its use is a fantastic but very specialized weapon and would be used in a wide open area-- usually remote-- like the area it was used. It is not the ground or underground bunker penetrating bomb. The concussive effect can be used near the openings of tunnels but there are other effective bombs for this purpose. Commanders have preferred smart accurate directed bombs that can strike more accurately-- dropping 100 smart bombs can achieve more military effect than one of these. It does have some effect to know we used it.

Regarding REITs these are deemed to be classic 'interest rate sensitive' equities. Therefore any meaningful upticks in interest rates will, at least in the short term, cause a knee-jerk reduction in unit price.

I invest primarily with a goal of generating a stream of dividend/distribution income. As such, fluctuations in unit price are of no real concern to me. What is more important is whether the distribution will be cut. For the vast majority of REITs, including all the ones that I own, I don't believe that that will be the case.

Re any hit to unit price this will likely be, in my opinion, greater for those REITs that have yields lower than 5%. I believe it will be less for those in the 7% plus range.

Also there are a huge variety of REITs and not all will react in the same way.

Let's look at some U.S. REITs that many people are not even aware of.

Comment: Quite a few people believe that the 'proof' of climate change is in the sophisticated mathematical climate models. Not so.  The science of climate change is based on a knowledge of physics and chemistry.  Anthropogenic global warming of the Earth's atmosphere is the inevitable conclusion based on understanding the carbon cycle, the green house effect, tracing sources through carbon dioxode isotopes, and so on.  The role of the mathematical models is different.  They follow on from our knowledge of climate, but predicting the average global temperature for a given future date is educated guess work.  And yes, science is often 'settled'.  Not all the conclusions we draw from the fundamentals of science, are, however.

Comment: An excerpt from my Grandfather's war diary October 24-31, 1916 where the 43rd Cameron Highlanders were on the front line. Please note the Canadian Corps was at Vimy well before the fateful battle of April 9 , 1917. The 43rd also was in that battle although my Grandfather was not.

24 to 31 We go to Vimy Ridge or Neuville St. Vaast
This is the worst bombed (mortars & minnys')
I have been in.
Short of men
92 holding a. brigade front
I am in an advance post
seven days without sleep (Oct. 24 evening to Oct 31)
& go to sleep on the fifth (Oct 29th)
day from exhaustion & am woke by officers.
I kill rats with my bayonet to keep awake.
Raining all night & no rum in the morning.
We feel, we feel rotten. The trench mortars
come too close & blow our trench in. Shortly
after I am blown up by a flying pig & my watch
broken. I escape. (unhurt)

Comment: While I strongly support this type of experience to help veterans, the positive effects are probably only temporary.   

Research has been done for decades on the use of rafting trips another "outdoor group bonding" experiences for the employees of corporations and, after few weeks back at work, everyone reverts to their old dysfunctional patterns.  In order to permanently change attitudes and behavior, changes have to be made in the "normal" environment that people work in every day. 

Thus, the most effective way of helping veterans would be to provide (and properly fund) support programs to improve ALL aspects of their daily lives including finding decent housing, finding a good job, and dealing effectively with medical and psychological problems.  

The federal government's veteran's assistance programs are NOT currently adequate due to underfunding by penny-pinching politicians, most of whom have never served a day in the military.

The only question that matters in this debate is whether or not that unborn human deserves dignity and the right to life which we expect to be bestowed on those of us outside the womb. Comment: I think I finally understand your confusion, Eric. I wrote in the article that the researchers had found captured ewes were very skinny and the birth rate was low. You argued that that might be due to hunters shooting the rams with the largest horns because you think those rams are the reason why sheep are fat and healthy. When I pointed out that the only physiological measure of the effect of hunting we have is the length of harvested rams' horns and their ages, I think you then argued that if the horn sizes were declining then that must mean the sheep weren't skinny. But the ewes (and presumably the rams) are skinny. And the number of ewes and rams have declined proportionally, which suggests that hunting is not the cause of the decline. And horn sizes and ages of harvested rams haven't declined. All of which points to nutrition, specifically (perhaps) the lack of protein, particularly in summer, when ewes should be fattening up for pregnancy, winter, and lambing early in spring.

Comment: 1/2
For seven years, every time they repeated the mantra “Repeal and Replace”, Republicans were lying: they had no plan to replace the ACA. The farce they rejected last week was cobbled together in haste. Conservatives didn’t like it because it didn’t hurt enough people. Liberals didn’t like it because it would have hurt so many people -- upwards of 24 million people would have lost health insurance and health care.
During the campaign and transition and even in the early days of his presidency, Trump promised simultaneous repair/replace, seamless transition, universal coverage, lower costs and better health care. He was lying. 
Ryan promised that when the Republicans replace the ACA, no-one, not one American, will be worse off than under the ACA. He was lying.
I don’t know how many people voted for Trump because they believed his promises about health care, but those who did ought to insist that he propose a health care plan that reflects those promises.

The proof was established by the VIPS (Veteran Intelligence Professionals for Sanity) and published in a letter to the president in Consortium news on the internet. VIPS did the forensics on the Guccifer 2.0 file and found it was produced somewhere in the eastern USA and that it was overlaid with a template as it can be bought on the internet to make it appear "Russian".

Why didn't the FBI do the forensics on the Guccifer 2.0 file? Why didn' the FBI insist on getting the DNC server? The answer to both is that they didn't need to, they already knew it was a leak. Otherwise they would have given some evidence that holds up to prove the hack. But they don't have any because it was a leak. That nixes both, Russian interference in the election and collusion by Trump et al. with Russia.

Comment: My bad, should have paid closer attention. Let's go on anther Greek expedition.

The "until" of Matt 1 = "heos hou" in Greek. Throughout the Gospels and the rest of the New Testament "heos hou" is placed not to demarcate "it was like this before and then after this moment it changed" but simply to indicate a "while"

Ex: "“Then Jesus went with them to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to his disciples,  ‘Sit here, "heos hou" I go yonder and pray.’ ” - Matt 26: 36. Obviously here it means "while". The context of Matthew 1: 18-25 is that the author is to underline the point that Mary has conceived without sexual relations. Mt 1:25 drives this home. Sure, more specificity in either direction indicating that they definitely had relations after Jesus' birth or that they never once had relations ever would be helpful but it's left ambiguous. The Greek doesn't meet your assumptions though. 

Just to be clear, to you Church fathers are "primitive" and apparitions are "ghosts". Right?

Comment: je me souviens: Local gas taxes generate $3 million per year that are being used to repair streets. But over $10 million per year would be needed just to keep up with repair needs, and even more to reduce the estimated $92-million backlog in streets needing fixing. The bond measure is needed on top of local gas taxes in order to have enough funding. (Unlike in the past, Eugene today receives hardly any funding from federal, state or county sources to maintain existing streets.)

Of course, voters could reject Ballot Measure 20-275 … but only if they want to allow the backlog to increase and to pay more later to reconstruct badly deteriorated streets. There is no free lunch and voters should not pretend that they can merely wish away the costs.

Again, Measure 20-275 is a prudent local tax to repair local streets that we all own and use. Voters should vote “yes.”

Learn more: http://www.eugene-or.gov/1086/Bond-Measures-to-Fix-Streets

Comment: Trudeau, a supposedly enlightened man, says his government has no intention of legalizing any drug besides marijuana.
But faced with thousands of deaths per year, it's apparent that the ethical contortions used to justify the continued prohibition of most illicit drugs are utterly without merit. 
When prohibition has been challenged in court, judges have ruled that government has a "valid interest in protecting society" via prohibition.
But when prohibition creates a black market controlled by criminal gangs, and exposes vulnerable addicts to (now massively increased) risk of death via unpredictable product, and considering the associated policing and health expenses... where is this "protection", and what is it costing us?
Finally, if drug use is a health issue, as even politicians increasingly suggest, then we should be looking at the health outcomes of drug policy -- and 2500+ deaths in a single year is about the worst policy outcome I can imagine.
End the drug war now.

Comment: Wind and solar energies have very unique and punctual applications, and making huge wind and solar farms is not one of them. Comment: While this is an annual gem unavailable elsewhere, there's a couple of issues here that need to be clarified.

First, the Vanguard VCE is NOT an analogue to XIC and ZCN which are broad market, it is a parallel to XIU, the TSX60 index. Good to mention VCN, which is a true substitute for the other two, but since VIU trades triple the number of shares daily to ALL the other TSX ETFs COMBINED, it would be nice to know this.

Which makes the dismissive XIU comments -- just for institutions, and not diversified -- even more misleading. When attention is paid to the paltry volume of the First Asset WXM and FXM to define their character, when they trade 15,000 shares (vs 3.5 million for XIU), wouldn't it be nice to know that the lack of diversification claimed for XIU is wholly attributable to its limitation of including only the biggest 60 market caps in the TSX?

All the others have comments detailing how they are different and why an investor might choose them, but ...?

Comment: Let's be realistic here. If the Government of Ontario did not offer all of these Feed in Tariffs, NONE of these projects would have been built because on their own they did not and continue not to make financial sense. Why not invest in a project that pays even if it is not producing anything? There's no downside risk on that baby.
In Ontario's case, all that investment in renewables has lead to a maximum 5% contribution to the total needs of the province. Sure, its easy to point to success stories elsewhere. They have the right combination of geography and/or  population density. Ontario has no Iowa to Oklahoma corridor where we can expect wind power of 400-500 w/m2 on a sustained basis. The right place to build windmills in Ontario is in the area of Hudson/James Bay between York Factory and Akimiski Island - about 100 km offshore. That's the only place in Ontario where wind power makes sense. Everything else is just show.

Comment: This is a case of someone pushing forward in the face of established science and nobody should have to pay for this woman's obstinance.

As a hydrogeologist in Alberta, I know that if you find gas in your water well all you have to do is send a sample to the University of Alberta and have them do isotopic analysis of the methane.  Biogenic gas produced by methane producing bacteria below 100 C has a distinct isotopic signature.  Thermal gas is cracked by temperatures above 200 C and also has a distinct isotopic signature.  The origin of the gas is important because the big oil companies are not extracting shallow biogenic gas in aquifer zones, only thermal gas from deep zones.  

If this woman did the proper sampling and tests, they would be conclusive.  All I can assume is that she has the data and it doesn't support her case against Encana or the regulator.  In my experience, there is no way that the regulator would not act on her behalf if she had supporting data.

Comment: Obviously you have missed the point. The Byzantine Liturgy is unreformed, it is ancient and time-honoured. The ritual has hardly altered over centuries.
The Roman Rite was in much the same position until 1970 when an ancient and time-honoured Rite was replaced by an ersatz, committee-fabricated ritual in order to appease Protestantism.
This is not about the language of the liturgy at all, it is about the very liturgy itself. The Patriarch of Moscow has heavily criticised the liturgical reforms subsequent to V2.
The major criticism of the Novus Ordo is not the language although the English leaves much to be desired, it is the deliberate downplaying of the sacrificial nature of the Mass.
Orthodox Churches ought to be wary of union with Rome if it reserves the right to Protestantise their liturgy by papal or conciliar decree.

Comment: No need to get priggish.  "You can play that intellectual game all you want" is totally unnecessary.  First, did you read my first comment, especially the words in brackets - WISHFUL THINKING.  Did I say it loud enough?  Secondly, go to any law dictionary, or reference source and learn the definition of dictum - "A statement of opinion or belief considered authoritative because of the dignity of the person making it. Comment: Father Reese wrote, "churches and religious believers feel that they are being vilified for simply maintaining centuries-old teaching." I expect that's right, that those people do believe that. But in that case, it's a disgraceful kind of belief, and it's no wonder that many LGBTQ people think religious believers are deplorable bigots. Inasmuch as homosexuality gets any attention in biblical literature and Catholic moral theology -- it does, but not very much, and never in a matter of central importance -- , it amounts to saying no more than that God is displeased by homosexual conduct; given that the orthodox Christian disposition does not assign normative value to Leviticus, there is nothing in our "teaching" that should recommend active persecution of LGBTQ people. And so for Christians to invest so much interest in opposing LGBTQ rights looks perverse, cruel, and in fact un-Christian. These people were always homophobes at heart, glad to be confirmed by a few minor Bible texts.

Comment: It's simple accounting: The Bank of Canada releases a certain amount of money to the economy, in the form of government spending. And it takes a certain amount back as taxes, fees etc. The difference is called the federal government deficit (or surplus if the taxes, fees etc exceed spending). So the size of deficit exactly equals the amount that was left in the account of somebody outside of the government, possibly abroad in case of trade deficit.
So yes, deficits don't matter by themselves. What matters is inflation and unemployment.

Comment: There's just no way that excessive speed isn't a factor in almost all these crashes (not accidents). Add in our local problem with drunk driving, and we've got the causes pretty much locked in. I used to drive a delivery truck on London Rd., and far less than 10% drive a safe speed.

Now, about that rumble strip idea. The roadways of Lame County don't have continuous, fixed-width shoulders. That means that sometimes cyclists can ride on the shoulder, and sometimes they must take the lane. Adding rumble strips makes this transition difficult enough that most cyclists will just take the lane and stay there, which would not be most folks preferred option in the absence of rumbles. Also, consider what happens when tourists come through. Bike touring is a growing part of our local tourism dollars and we shouldn't be creating hostile infrastructure for these visitors who tend to spend more money than most.

Comment: Some background is needed first:  After the return of the exiles beginning in 1990, powerful figures such as Thabo Mbeki and Joe Slovo got black people in South Africa to accept a crucial reduction in the political power previously held by white voters from the time of the constitution of the Union of South Africa in 1910. 

In his article "Reform lethal slate politics", (2016 ) Trewhela explains just how this occurred: @ http://www.politicsweb.co.za/opinion/reform-lethal-slate-politics

This was the power to choose and remove each individual MP and provincial councillor for themselves, organised in electoral constituencies.  The black electorate did not realise that in gaining the franchise, they were being deprived at the same time of one of its most essential qualities: the right to choose and get rid of individual political representatives directly.  Frederik van Zyl Slabbert´s (2003) report on the necessary electorial reform was never heeded by the Mbeki or Zuma administrations.

Comment: Med school at 20,000 per year at UBC is a bargain compared to dental school at 60000.   What ordinary exceptionally bright Canadian can afford these rates?  The professions are closing except to exceptionally bright Canadians who either have wealthy parents or are willing and able to start off their careers very deeply in debt.  These changes should  be made to close the loopholes that  are offered to everyone who incorporates just to avoid tax (such as journalists) but there needs to be adjustments such as the ability to treat required educational expenses of self-employed professionals as capital expenditures to be amortized over a number of years.  An education costs as much as machinery and is as necessary.  Going into a "knowledge economy" is going to require a re-jigging, not only of expectations as the economy completes a transition from hands on manufacturing but also of the tax code.  We need a new Royal Commission on Taxation.  We're past the ability to tweak.

Comment: There are many ways to interpret natural language "as it is written".  If you want certainty from something "as it is written" you need mathematics, not natural language.  

Laws are written in natural language, not mathematics, so they require interpretation.

A reasonable interpretation of a law takes into account not only the letter of the law, but also its spirit, i.e., the problem the law intended to address.

I haven't studied the history of immigration legislation much, except to know that it arose midway through our country's history and had its genesis in exclusion acts to keep out certain ethnic groups.  Nevertheless, I'm relatively certain the idea behind the current immigration law is to keep out "bad hombres," not break up families.

As the judge said, Ortiz is a "good hombre", which means he's the kind of guy our laws were designed to let in.  Given that, do we want to break up his family?

Comment: Actually it makes perfect sense at any investment dollar level. If you had only $50k would you hold 30 different stocks? Of course you wouldn't, so why would you with $1 million?

I started out with $22k from my company RRSP after they closed back in the 90s and purchased 3 stocks. Over the years of day trading I've never held more than 15 stocks and typically hold 8 to 10 stocks on average.

As for SFIs question, diversity was never meant for individual investors. It came from large retail and institutional investing. At some point CFPs and other investment advisors starting pushing the diversity notion onto individual investors. Its also not just a matter of commissions, you don't mitigate any risk holding 30 stocks. If the market crashes all 30 stocks will decline in value.

There are really just two risks, market crashes which you can wait through. The other is buying penny or speculative stocks. Diversification in 30 or more stocks doesn't protect you in either instance.

Comment: Here we go again...  The Vocation Olympics.  

This topic was pretty hot a couple of years ago.  

To summarize what researchers found:

1)  The large number of men and women religious that we saw 50, 60 years ago was actually the anomaly.  Smaller numbers of men and women religious were the norm previously
2)  The decline in numbers is a return to the norm
3)  Because of the smaller number of habited orders vs non-habited, one person joining will have a greater numerical impact.  1 person joining a 10-person community is a 10% increase.  1 person joining a 100-person community is a 1% increase.  It is still one person joining.

Please...  The Vocation Olympics pops up from time to time, creates a lot of sturm und drang, and resolves nothing.  Leaves a lot of bad feelings, however.

How about we all decide not to participate in these particular Olympics?

In the first instance it means that innocent individuals are being investigated and possibly charged with a serious crime. Let's get to the bottom of it, and make any adjustments necessary.

I think Peter Zumthor has said it best in his book "Thinking Architecture" where he says;

"Every new work of architecture intervened in a specific historical situation. It is essential to the quality of the intervention that the new building should embrace qualities which can enter into a meaningful dialogue with the existing situation. For if the intervention is to find its place, it must make us see what already exists in a new light. We throw a stone into the water. Sand swirls up and settles again. The stir was necessary. The stone found its place. But the pond is no longer the same."

Comment: That is incorrect.

Aliens in the U.S. have essentially the same rights as citizens for many purposes because of the 5th and 14th Amendments’ language, but aliens do not have constitutional rights against the U.S. government outside its territory. This principle goes back to 1896 and the case of Wong Wing v. United States, 163 U.S. 228 (1896). All persons in the U.S., therefore, have constitutional rights. Among these are the right to equal protection of the law and the right to due process.

An immigrant, legal or illegal, prosecuted under the criminal code has the right to due process, a speedy and public trial, and other rights protected by the Fifth and Sixth Amendments. The National lawyers Guild sets the various rights for non-citizens out in this publication:
https://www.nlg.org/know-your-rights-english/

Comment: The accounts should be used in regards to the tax advantages and restrictions.  The actual investments aside from the tax implications generally don't matter.  In other words you will generally try and shelter investments that attract the most tax in a cash account and avoid investments that incur non recoverable taxes (e.g. foreign taxes) or lose preferential tax treatment (eligible dividends) within the registered account.  But it all depends on the total portfolio.

The fact that some people choose to use a TFSA as a bank account or short term savings account doesn't negate the fact that it offers as good and sometimes superior long term tax advantages over a RRSP account.  The liquidity factor is entirely dependent upon the objectives and needs of the individual.  Since part of the objective here is put away $15K and forget it the TFSA, RRSP and even a cash account are all valid options and the decision should consider the overall portfolio objective and longer range tax planning.

Comment: What has become the "downtown relief line" was first presented to me as a Toronto federal MP in about 1978.

The then plan was to run it south from Fairview Mall to the proposed Leslie barns and then west to the city centre on either Queen or King (where stations had already been roughed in on both the Yonge line and the Spadina - University line).

Then, the Davis government stopped funding subway infrastructure and started funding community recreation infrastructure. Despite the construction of a much shortened Sheppard line from Yonge to Fairview Mall, the short extension of the Yonge subway line north to Finch  and the nearly completed extension of the Spadina - University line to York University, Toronto has never recovered its vision (or the Province's vital support) in building its much needed subway infrastructure.

Mayor Tory is right to stress completing Toronto's subway infrastructure before expanding beyond Toronto's boundaries.

Comment: There are circumstances under which custodians can be prosecuted for violating their responsibilities as custodians. See AS 09.50.010 and AS 11.56.758. The issue of bail has many elements. Among other factors, there's a constitutional right to bail (a corallary to innocent until proven guilty), appellate court rulings and statutes set out when pre-trial release must be allowed, it's legally impermissible to impose criminal penalties for strict liability offenses, human beings are unpredictable, judges can't foretell the future, and keeping people in jail is extremely expensive in a time of stretched budgets. This 2016 Pew report explains the financial factors in Alaska quite well: http://www.pewtrusts.org/~/media/assets/2016/12/alaskas_criminal_justice_reforms.pdf

Comment: The DEFICIT declined, the DEBT continued to go up.
Although comparing personal finance to government debt is not exact, let's try.  I mean no disrespect to military or anyone in this analysis, just trying to illustrate DEFICIT vs DEBT.
Say my salary is $1000/mo.
I buy two automobiles I cannot afford, on loan (Iraq and Afghanistan), payments $2000/mo, but I choose to lower my salary (taxes).  My name is W.
So now my salary is $500/mo, but my payments $2000/mo.  I have a monthly DEFICIT of $1500/mo.  So my DEBT is climbing at $1500/mo, and I have to pay interest on the debt too.  So DEBT keeps climbing by $1500/mo plus interest.
BO did his best to dump the automobiles, and he did get the payments way down.  And he did his best to raise the salary to cover the payments, but of course Republicans don't believe in paying for what you buy especially if you are rich, so Congress blocked him as best they could.
Despite all that our deficit is reduced.

On the cruise ship, I see people walking in circles around the ship. At the meals, I see healthier choices and smaller portions.

What I haven't seen anywhere is lots of obesity. I haven't seen piles of chips and other high calorie, high fat, high sugar, etc... food being consumed in large amounts as if people are one meal away from a world wide apocalypse.  Why not look to Europe for better lifestyle choices and not so much for universal health insurance choices.  (We need to quit confusing health care and health insurance.)

* Farmers everywhere who are under stress with less water are all resistant to changes in how they use the water (see California). Only the threat of extinction will get the farmers' attention.

* I always wondered how much water is lost to evaporation by throwing it up in the air on a hot day from center-pivot irrigators.  Just like us city-dwellers, they should set their automated systems to be watering only at night.  Common sense.

Comment: The Oregon State Bar's handling of ethics complaints against members is a sham. 

I filed a complaint against a local attorney, working for developers' interests, who wrote an e-mail to the Eugene Deputy City Attorney encouraging her to “share word of Mr. Conte's attempted extortion with others in the city.”

This was a clear violation of ethics rule 4.4 (a) "In representing a client or the lawyer’s own interests, a lawyer shall not use means that have no substantial purpose other than to embarrass, delay, harass or burden a third person ***.

Despite having a copy of the e-mail, Helen Hierschbiel, the OSB General Counsel, dismissed the complaint.

My rejoinder summarized: 

_"If the position description for OSB General Council requires shielding members of the bar from accountability, you would appear well-qualified. If the position is supposed to maintain public confidence in the integrity of the Oregon Bar, you appear to to be a poor choice."_

-- Paul

Comment: To pedophile apologist Ingrid Diane Johnson, here is a more current and more widely respected source that completely disagrees with you:

"Pessimism About Pedophilia"

"There is no cure, so the focus is on protecting children.

Pedophilia, the sexual attraction to children who have not yet reached puberty, remains a vexing challenge for clinicians and public officials. Classified as a paraphilia, an abnormal sexual behavior, researchers have found no effective treatment. Like other sexual orientations, pedophilia is unlikely to change. The goal of treatment, therefore, is to prevent someone from acting on pedophile urges — either by decreasing sexual arousal around children or increasing the ability to manage that arousal. But neither is as effective for reducing harm as preventing access to children, or providing close supervision."

Comment: Those who are dissatisfied with the coverage given to any topic in a particular news source are free to supplement their search for coverage in any other news source.

That's why I read much more than just the Globe and Mail. It covers only so much for many different reasons (lack of space, political slant, editorial focus, awareness, and more), after all it's not perfect. The Star, the CBC, the New York Times, the BBC, the Guardian, the South China Morning Post, Le Monde, Ha'aretz, Die Welt, Der Spiegel, Nature, JAMA, and more...all get their read. I even read "fringe" news sources to see what the fringe is going on about.

If what I'm interested in knowing about isn't in one source, I search around. Complaining about lack of coverage is childish when there's a whole world of coverage out there.

We're all free to stop reading what doesn't satisfy us.

Comment: At the request of the owners, I declawed many thousands of cats( including my own) over 45 years of veterinary practice . At approximately 6 mos of age most kittens are neutered(painful?) under general anaesthetic and were often declawed at the same time. We always hospitalized 48 - 72 hours post surgery in the case of declaws under a regime of painkillers/antibiotics. Very,very few complications were ever observed. The only difficulties seemed to be in older cats , declawed because of badly scratched owners or damaged furniture. To suggest that owners will ever clip their cats nails on a weekly basis is laughable & naive! The comment that a cat became nasty after a declaw is equally silly! Minx, our first cat, serves as my inspiration. She was an elegant Burmese who lived for over 20 years in rural Aurora summering in Muskoka and going out to daily & successfully reduce the rodent population. Being declawed it didnt bother me that she often massaged the new furniture. John Mollard

Comment: There are one Helluva lot more $9 - $12/hr. jobs in this town than there are $90 - $120/hr. jobs.   The person working at a place like Sports Authority, other than a few college students and retirees, is working two or three jobs to keep an apartment and a beater with a heater going and put food on the table.   Lots of them have made bad choices, principally kids they can't afford and marriages they didn't have; there is a fair amount of bad habits too, but that is the Alaska environment.   When that person loses that job, they have to immediately find another one, and if they don't the next step is welfare and the next is leaving the State.   That's an empty apartment, and before long enough empty apartments puts property owners and managers in bankruptcy.   I saw this movie in the '80s.   The only thing that ended the downward spiral then was the Exxon Valdez; Alaska needs a disaster or a war.   Don't make any big purchases unless you can pay cash.

Comment: Very odd to create and a support a petition into something people clearly know nothing about. If a doctor makes a medical decision...do people petition the hospital to reprimand the doctor?

First, the standard of proof is proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Which means that it is not whether something may have happened or likely happened or even probably happened. It is whether the Crown has proved its case beyond a reasonable doubt. Would you convict a friend for assault if his alleged victim was drunk, and could only remember that your friend hit him but nothing else about his night?

Second, there is a section of criminal code which makes it impossible to consent to sex when extremely intoxicated. In this case, it would be shocking, if that section was not raised by the Crown and considered by the judge.

The take away point is, read the judge's reasons, before jumping to conclusions.

Comment: As the article stated, Hydro’s 900-megawatt Burrard Thermal Plant is "the cleanest operating natural gas standby plant in North America," but you are arguing that it's misguided to choose plants like this over the dam. If you ignore the research that dams' reservoirs emit methane gas, this may seem to make sense.

But one thing about generating plants is they can be closed relatively quickly, and indeed, older technology generating plants are being shut down. The closure of the huge Navajo Generating Station in Arizona was recently announced, closing 25 years earlier than planned, and the closure of the Burrard plants proves this too.

But dams? Sorry. but that's a 100 year commitment to operate no matter what new tech comes along. And even if you did want to shut it down and drain the flooded lands, that would also take tons of money, and the drained land would be wrecked for at least a generation. 

The Site C dam would be a permanent, expensive mistake, so let's not build it.

But times change and criminals began to be better armed than law enforcement. .357 Mags started to show up, ruffling feathers. In the late 60's or early 70's , in Newhall, CA, cops found themselves in the middle of a shootout with a group far better armed than they were. If memory serves at least 4 officers were killed, and officers actually went to a gun store an seized some amount of AR15's to use during the fight-probably VietNam vets. Following that law enforcement began to adopt high capacity semi autos because that is what they were facing on the street. Things continue to change and law enforcement has no choice but to adapt.  I don't want to see another situation where, in the middle of an incident, the cops are scrambling for equipment.

Comment: https://www.lymedisease.org/lyme-basics/lyme-disease/chronic-lyme/

With all due respect a quick look on google found this link that contradicts your statement that " The naturopath diagnosed "chronic Lyme disease" which is an entity that does not exist", 


http://www.healthline.com/health/lyme-disease-chronic-persistent#Treatment7



When diagnosed at an early stage, standard treatment for Lyme disease is a course of oral antibiotics that lasts about two to three weeks. Doxycycline, amoxicillin, and cefuroxime axetil are the most common medications prescribed. Other antibiotics or an intravenous treatment may be necessary depending on your condition and other symptoms.
Treatment for chronic Lyme disease is often focused on reducing pain and discomfort caused by symptoms. Prescription or over-the-counter pain relievers may be used to treat joint pain. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs) and intra-articular steroids can be used to treat problems such as joint swelling.

Comment: there are several different types of audit.  the one referred to in hart's situation is a financial audit - which primary purpose is to measure the accuracy of an entity's financial condition at  a certain date.  there are management audits, wihich main purpose is to review management's control over processes, to determine if proper control is instituted to preserve assets and promote efficiency of a entity.  there is the foresic audit, which main purpose to see if there were any mismanagement by people running the entity, which may uncover criminal wrongdoing.  an irs audit is audit of an individual or entities tax returns, to determine if all income are reported and expenses claimed are correct and supported.  it may uncover criminality but a majority of irs audits are settled civilly or administratively.   any audit can uncover criminality but that is not the purpose of all audits  please remember this, as I will test you six months from now to see it you learned anything.

Comment: I have been an Iditarod fan for many years; the last several years, it seems like the race has become more of an endurance sprint race.  There is a big difference between a sprint and a marathon. If people want a race to go for long distance speed, it may be time for the races to become stage races: a daily sprint to a daily finish line, then rest for the dogs. Remember, originally, "Redington had two reasons for organizing the long-distance Iditarod Race: to save the sled dog culture and Alaskan huskies, which were being phased out of existence due to the introduction of snowmobiles in Alaska; and to preserve the historical Iditarod Trail between Seward and Nome." - from the ITC website. The race has changed tremendously since then, and as it evolves, the question that the ITC and fans need to ask themselves is: are we celebrating speed at any cost, or Alaskan heritage? Personally, I'm not that interested in speed.

Comment: We do need extremely tight rules to protect privacy on private property. A friend was telling me that she was in her bedroom folding clothes when a recreational drone with camera paused right outside her second story window up in the hills outside of Fairbanks. By the time she got downstairs and outside, she couldn't figure out where it went, but that sort of nonsense should result in some stiff penalties. Unfortunately, it's so incredibly easy to do and as my friend is discovering, it's impossible to track who just (possibly) viewed you naked in your bedroom on a second story on a wooded lot where neighbors' homes have no sight line ... the very place you should have an expectation of privacy. It just gets worse from there and soon privacy will be this vaguely remembered old-fashioned concept.

And, yeah, it could be used as a fascist tool. The government has already shown itself to have no respect for our private communications, so why wouldn't they use drones to spy on us?

Comment: Carbon pollution imposes costs already by affecting the climate. Those costs are not currently included in the cost of production.  Why not? It's called an 'externality'.

A carbon tax brings those costs back to the producer of the carbon pollution which they will pass along in their cost of product to consumers.  This is a good thing. The consumer can make a more intelligent choice about the value of the product taking into account the pollution costs. 

All in favour of market solutions to allocate scare resources optimally when such opportunities are available say 'aye!'  All others please proceed to the 'regulation' option.

Comment: "It just seems the left doesn't want to engage in debate"

It's not that the left doesn't want to engage in debate. It's that the left wonders what the end condition of the "debate" is. When there is objective measurement that global temperatures are steadily rising, and that glaciers and ice sheets are melting, it seems like at least the first part of the debate (whether the planet is warming) is pretty well settled. We don't know exactly how much is human-caused, and how much is natural, but we have a decent understanding of the mechanisms that cause warming, and the only responsible course of action is to do what we can to slow or reverse them.

Meanwhile, climate change deniers would rather stretch the "debate" out in perpetuity. But this is very much a "ticking clock" scenario. If it isn't real, but we act on it anyway, then the worst case scenario is that we <gasp!> reduce pollution unnecessarily. If it is real, and we fail to reverse it, then we likely get wiped out.

Comment: Personally, I don't find that public recognition is that great a motivator, although some people feel differently. But I wonder at some people's strong need to eliminate awards. Would it not be better and healthier all around to teach our students to rejoice in their classmates' accomplishments and use them as inspiration to reach higher themselves? What are we really teaching them if we tell them they should resent other people's accomplishments as a judgment on themselves? 

My family has coached minor sports, and we tell our kids that if they were beaten by an opponent who played honourably, that is somebody to respect and learn from. Resenting the accomplishments of others never helps you achieve yourself.

Comment: I concede that I am surprised by this quotation. In a first draft of my reply, I referenced the Church's economic teaching more broadly (which is what I really mean to say!), but then edited it to conform to you specific reference to Leo (yes, the pope ;-} )

Comment: To be in Tier 3, at the very end of eligibility in '06, you'd be more than halfway through your career right now for 20, but even then, most go to 25 unless they're prior military retirees so they can get medical coverage which kicks in at 25. If they're ex-military, they're probably in their late 50s retiring at best (18-38yoa military, 38-58yoa cop/fire), or if they're not, typically they're going to be in their mid-40s (21-46yoa) assuming they follow the absolute most expedient track, which almost none do. I wanted to be a cop from the age of 15 and learned, trained and focused on it and I wasn't hired until I was 24, meaning I'd retire at 44-49yoa.

Given median life expectancy in the state of 76.34 years, and factoring these careers shorten lifespans not lengthen, lets assume they retire for 20 years at $45,000/year retirement. Thats $900k not millions. Most won't retire exactly 25 because medical might not kick in right away depending on tier as well.

Comment: During the Cold War, we had "brinksmanship", with the Cuban Missile Crisis as the highlighting event. Comment: I general, I agree with what Michael has written here, but I would point out that the big banks and mortgage bankers largely responded to what the market demanded of them in the early-to-mid 2000s. People who couldn't qualify for conventional mortgages wanted to buy nice homes and pushed brokers and bankers to develop new and less risk-averse strategies and vehicles. Then, as the market went up, they wanted to refinance, buy second homes, and lead the good life -- and once again, the market responded. Admittedly, they quickly learned how to dangle a very appetizing carrot in front of the public's nose, but it was always a two-way street and we were all partly responsible for believing that the real estate bubble would never bust. I think it's dangerous to always point the finger at the other guy and absolve ourselves of complicity in our problems. It's also a little dangerous to think that federal regulations are the best response to the greed within our hearts.

Comment: It seems at first glance to be an improvement over C-51, especially around issues of accountability. However, the key anti-privacy portion of that legislation remains intact in C-59. C-51 contained the Security of Canada Information Sharing Act (SCISA), which allowed the sharing of any kind of collected personal information between government departments. Critics call this the “total information awareness” approach. 
From the Toronto Star: [both bills] "permit information sharing across government for an incredibly wide range of purposes, most of which have nothing to do with terrorism...the scope of sharing is exceptionally broad, covering 17 government institutions with government granting itself the right to expand sharing to other departments... effectively neuters the core protections found in the Privacy Act by opening the door to the very kind of information sharing that the law is intended to prevent." The Star article is about C-51 but applies to C-59 as well.

Comment: Curious as to why you've purposefully conflated two different definitions of socialism.  Why insist on defining socialism as communist theory does? What does that have to do with the topic at hand?

Socialism is the political & economic system that exists, to one degree or another, in EVERY modern economy on earth. It holds that economic exchange should be subject to and controlled by and on behalf of the people with their interests as the prime purpose for all economic activity.

The mixture varies considerably. Singapore probably has the least socialist aspects in its economy yet the state has considerable say from the top down as to what economic goals will be pursued. Historically, several Scandinavian countries have been considered the most socialist in their political and economic make-up yet with market forces remaining at the core of their system. Socialism has long existed in the U.S. originating in the 19th century and expanding significantly at the beginning of the 20th.

Comment: You're quite right, there are areas where the "local culture" is far more like what we experienced as "youngsters."  Unfortunately, that subculture has become the exception and not (I'd say far from) the rule.

With physical mobility, the extended family has been scattered across our vast nation.  Most Grandchildren see their Grandparents once or twice a year (after all they may live thousands of miles away) and, on the flip side, most Grandparents get to spend little time with their Grandchildren.  We no longer have a functioning multi-generational lifestyle.  Kids and parents, then, when they "leave home", it usually Kids (young men and women) spending their time with their "age" peers.  Young people don't have the opportunity to both "give and receive" from Grandparents.  Those who do are the fortunate exceptions.  

The larger our metropolitan areas become and the further removed young people become from their families, the less we see of that important intergenerational contact

Comment: At least we can call Joseph Boyden a Canadian, and that's good enough for me. I consider Mr. Boyden one this country's finest writers, and I hope that this invasion of his privacy won't affect his ability to continue writing these remarkable stories.
This whole cultural appropriation debate is nonsense. Writers must be free to imagine and compose their own stories as they see fit. It's strange that nobody has ever criticized William Shakespeare for culturally appropriating stories about Denmark, Scotland and Italy --particularly Rome--all places he never visited in his lifetime. If they had and he stopped writing his plays as a result, we would not have Hamlet, Macbeth, Romeo & Juliet or Julius Caesar today.
My advice to Joseph Boyden: Joe, when you are writing your sentences, don't hold punches. You are a very important writer. Keep it up.

Comment: Another issue that has been ignored is the unfair or inequitable treatment of homeowners and other asset owners regarding income on capital gains. In a logical world all income would be taxed the same. This would include salaries, capital gains on home sales, professional income, and capital gains on stock or other asset sales. This would go a long way to take some of the heat out of the real estate and stock markets, as both are inflated assets (aka bubbles). But if one wishes to maintain the capital gains exemptions on homes, it could be made more equal if it was a once in a lifetime thing and it was only for the average value of a home in Canada at the time of the claim, so the playing field was more equitable or equal. Increasing the holding period from one year to a five year minimum, with the holder being required to have paid personal income tax in Canada for that period might also help. These are all understandable and addressable issues.

Comment: JC,

That is not a very good analogy. For one, you don't actually possess the right to have a lawful society, thought you do benefit from one in Canada. Second, a common test placed on ones freedom to act in society without hindrance is the harm principle. Using this test, one can can clearly establish that those who exceed the speed limit are more likely to cause accidents that could physically and demonstrably harm others. Therefore, they are prohibited from doing so by the law. Ones unwillingness to use another individuals desired pronoun or support their chosen way of life does not sufficiently harm the other in a demonstrable fashion. Hurt feelings is not enough to meet the harm principle test or we'd be in a world of problems as everyone would be before the court for hurting others feelings one way or another. One should have the right to their chosen gender identity, no question, but that right need not require others to do anything but not impede their choice.

Comment: While simply "outlawing" panhandling seems an 'easy and simple" answer, it is NOT.  That's because "panhandling" has been repeatedly found to be a constitutionally protected First Amendment expression.  YOU CANNOT LEGALLY BAN ALL PANHANDLING IN PUBLIC PLACES.  There's an excellent little "book" entitled: "A Guide to Regulating Panhandling", put out by the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation (http://www.cjlf.org/publications/RegulatePanhandling.pdf) It provides some excellent background and understanding of the many issues involved in addressing panhandling.  Gary Crum

Comment: Can you give us a source for your homeless density claim? I don't believe it. As compared with Portland, Seattle, San Francisco? Population density is different in different cities. I would expect homelessness density to vary with population density, other things being equal, such as number unemployed or underemployed, prevailing wages, supply of apartments, etc.. 

I guess you could compare Eugene with a city of similar size. I'm constantly reading on Google News about other cities in which homelessness is a big problem -- especially for the homeless -- and a political issue, because it's the public face of poverty that a lot of people don't want to see.

Also the one night homeless counts, that local governments do all over the US, are notoriously inaccurate, because camping bans make it necessary to hide from the cops. Our best estimate is 2,000-3,000 at any one time.

In my experience, Eugene has always been a hard place to make a living.

Comment: Hi Richard:  It's possible to agree to give someone money just like it's possible to agree to sex.  It's only robbery when you don't consent to somebody taking your money.  Yet the Crown doesn't have to prove that a victim of robbery didn't consent to giving their money away.  Why is that different?

If a victim of robbery were drunk and unable to remember all the details of the incident, would the courts say it can't be proven that you didn't consent to give away your money, and so acquit the robber?  I don't think that happens.  So why would anyone be comfortable with a different standard of proof for sexual assault?

There can always be doubts raised -- it's what is reasonable doubt that we're debating.

Comment: What I'm curious about is the fees in a mutual fund whose constituent investments are also mutual funds.  Each fund has a cost made up of its trading expenses and many other things. The return of each fund is net of its costs. So when the fund that is made up of other funds says that its MER is say 2.3% I'm guessing that doesn't include all of the expenses for the funds under it. Rather its MER is just its own cost which is subtracted from the net returns of its constituent elements to determine the subscriber's return on his investment product that invests in other investment products. I'd be interested to have somebody confirm or contest my interpretation stating your qualification or specific source of knowledge. Thank you.

Comment: Fair question. I wish I were paid for this, but I am not. I'm moved to write about M97 because taxes are always a hard sell, and there are big $ fighting M97. It needs people speaking out for it to get a fair hearing. As Jack Bogle (one of my favorite wise men) says about the current challenges: "They're skating on thin ice because states and municipalities will need to raise taxes to pay their bills. And nobody likes that." I also comment on PERS issues, sometimes on race and education and religion and other issues. I work more than full time, but like many others I find the comments sections of news sites to be a fascinating place. I post anonymously partly because I do some teaching and I don't want my students to think that they have to agree with me and partly because I post controversial ideas I'm just working through and don't want them published under my name. I regard the comments section as a place of lively conversation. I am grateful for the anonymity offered.

There are only a handful of developed countries in the world that could make a similar claim over the same time period.

Comment: Col. Kalsi wonders why we permit monuments to the Confederate losers, since we and our allies never permitted anybody to build monuments to Nazi leaders.  The answer to this is simply that they were two very different historical contexts.  In the 19th century, virtually no white Americans considered Negroes their actual equals.  But many opposed slavery on moral grounds, and on the grounds that the country could not go on being half-slave, half-free.  But the slavery issue was not the focus and motivation of the men fighting. Their motivation was sectional.  The chivalry still taken seriously in military culture at that time required respect for one's enemy, and even friendship after the war ended.  None of these cultural factors were in play in occupied Germany.  We did not regard the defeated enemy as honorable and, as total victors, we claimed the prerogative of reestablishing a different political culture in place of Nazism.

Comment: This utopic concept, "Case For Stewardship Logging" is out of touch with the reality of logging in Western Oregon... dominated by the landscape-scale clearcut, burn, spray and replant norm. 

Often maligned Federal forest management and logging is not the problem. 
The problem is industrial logging, accounting for 80% of  Oregon's annual timber harvest; harvest rates increasing with shifts of large forest ownerships to REITs; and the financial incentives to cut, replant, and cut again in less than 40 years.

Protecting ecological integrity and the public's entwined resources within private forests, like water and wildlife, from rampant industrial forest liquidation will realistically require more restrictive forest practice rules and penalizing taxation.

Achieving this will require end runs, like voter initiatives, around Oregon's corporately controlled legislature.

I say this have witnessed 50 years of unchallenged forest liquidation in the Pacific West as a forest professional.

Comment: Obamacare is a bad model but it's a model that was forced upon him by Republicans. Obama originally proposed the creation of a 'public option,' or government-sponsored insurance program that would have competed against private insurance providers, which had no chance of coming to fruition given the vehement and organized opposition of vested private interests. Obamacare, then, was a compromise that employed government subsidies combined with financial penalties for being uninsured to achieve something close to forced universal coverage (as opposed to actual universal care) utilizing the existing overly expensive private health insurance structure. What could possibly go wrong? The fact that almost 50% of Americans still support Obamacare really is a testament to how terrible the Republican alternative (i.e. the old system) is considered to be by so many Americans.

Comment: You really have no idea how the program works do you? No the houses are not free - they are never advertised as such. The houses are build or refurbished to current energy star ratings which means the utilities payments are peanuts. Yes you sign a mortgage, but the mortgage payment is typically LOWER than what these people are paying for apartments - they all have to go through a financial analysis to show that and to show that they would qualify for the reduced mortgage. Not to mention the families get additional ownership through the fact that each family has to 'donate' 500 sweat equity hours helping volunteer to build other houses for other families. Please, understand the program before you crap on it.

Comment: I think that teaching children the concept of dualism is important. The world is not always right or wrong, black and white, or binary 0 or 1. There are shades of grey, degrees of right and wrong, and there are an infinite set of numbers between 0 and 1.
My statistics teacher in second year university said it has not been proven that smoking caused cancer. He was a smoker and dualist. In 4th year, statistics course I worked in the smoking lab to collect data on cigarette tar vs # of puffs. I don't remember the statistical results. I remember the discoloured filters with tar and the smell of the lab and my clothing while collecting the data samples.
Senses and logic may not be binary statistical indicators but they can save your life. 
I also learned that smokers who cut down the number of cigarettes per day were still able to extract the same amount of nicotine and tar as before. Counter intuitive yes!

Comment: I never watch them.  Couple of reasons.  

Since they are aimed at a mass market, the legal systems are mostly modeled after either California or New York.  The law is very State-specific, particularly on the criminal side.  Grand Jurys are done differently in Oregon, California and New York, for example.  

There is also the total difference between small legal offices and larger offices.  Even in Oregon the We The People Firms in Portland have little to do with legal practice in much smaller offices and communities.

Then there is always the simplification of the law, the facts, and the investigations, whether in a criminal or a civil case that has to be built in to a television movie or series.  

Law is basically boring repetitive Work!  Research is mandatory.  Without  Detailed preparation, you will lose!  When you ask a question or hear one being asked in a courtroom of any witness, if you don't already know the answer, you are not prepared.  

That doesn't happen without work.

Comment: Tiny home communities exist across the US, and they do little to create slums. If anything, they provide income to cities on infill, vacant and underdeveloped land. They allow for gentle densification without major rezoning, and can add subtlety and creativity to neighbourhoods. They are no different than a laneway house, except our definition of a tiny house is moveable and therefore on wheels. Land cost is an issue and we are exploring this through our Go Tiny project. We are in talks with Vancity and RBC to explore tiny house mortgages and how a tiny house would impact land value. Lots more to explore!

Comment: If the snake is not in the house, did they look under the hood of their cars ? They go to warm places, hot water pipes, near furnace or hot water heater. 
They are very good at getting into small spaces like a pipe.
One of my sister's pythons got inside a toilet that was not hooked up with no water in it. It would curl up inside the toilet and pop its head out now and then. In it's case, it was looking for a place that wasn't too hot or too cold because the outdoor temperatures were over 110 degrees. 
Once one of her larger snakes went outside in the cooler weather and curled up under the hood of the car, on a warm engine block.
If the snake is found alive they may wish to get a chip tracker put under the skin  or get a snake collar with a tracker on it. 
It is a beautiful snake! Hope it's found alive.

Comment: "Stotts, of the Inuit Circumpolar Council, said it has always been a challenge to get outsiders to think about the Arctic."  The key word is "outsiders". And I have no problem with being labeled as an American Native.  And I don't believe in there being an "us and them" in America. There is a relationship there which makes us part of America, One Nation, "Allies" if you prefer, if for no other reason than mutual self-interests.

Comment: Now that this couple has a good income they want the accoutrements that defined success for their parents. Home renovations, cottage, stay at home mom, new car every so often, etc. They run the risk of over doing it. Having denied themselves for so long they are like a starving man presented with a table overflowing with  food. He will eat himself to death.

Chris's basic question is: how long must we wait before we have everything we want? He does not need an adviser to tell him this. If they spend only what they have and do not borrow they can plan their spending for years to come. If they borrow they incur interest expenses which increase the costs of their dreams, maybe putting them out of reach.

The issue of paying off the mortgage may be a red herring. They should think more carefully about their future before spending. I recommend building in a contingency to cover expenses not covered by their current budget which appears a bit light for a family of five.

Comment: I am a secularist and have no taste for any particular religion. But religion should be afforded more credit than you give it. Consider Canadian history itself. The Temperance movement had a particularly Christian flavour to it, and it was under the guidance of religion that the Temperance movement won voting rights for women in Canada. Or how about the Social Gospel movemment of western Canada, which used Protestant teachings to rally labourers and farmers to unionize, winning them better working conditions. Or the famed Tommy Douglas, who was a preacher, also influenced by Social Gospel, whose witness of suffering eventually kicked off a personal crusade that after a decade led to the formation of social programs like medicare?

I am not affiliated with any religion, but as a device, it was more than just a coping mechanism, and you don't have to be a person of religion to sincerely appreciate that.

Comment: No nation can count on another to be a friend or ally in all respects and in perpetuity.  The US is something of a special case where its power, both military and monetary, is better to be on your side than not.  The question is how to deal with its varying political philosophy, especially now that there's an administration that breaks all traditions of political protocol.  Some see that as a threat, others see it as refreshing; either way, it's more of a "change" than what we've experienced in Canada since 2015.  Yes, the U.S. administration is a different elephant now, and we're better to get on dealing with it rather than try to brawl with it and lose.

As for the U.S. being in moral decline, if you think it's just happening now, you've missed the boat entirely because the precipice of moral decline was broached in the 1960's, exacerbated since then largely by mostly Liberal governments, a leftist entertainment media and abetted by a ratings-hungry news media.

Comment: It astounds me that we have survived so long and so well without an "original parts only" law as to public restroom use."  I do not wish to be astounded by who will be the parts inspectors. 

More to the point, it seems to me that there will be less confusion amongst those proverbially confused little children, and much less fright amongst those proverbially easily scared horses, if we stick to a few simple rules that have largely served us well since, well, forever. One, use restrooms consistent with the parts you got, rather than the ones you had or wished you had. Two, don't confuse dumping stations with inspection stations.

Now, having become intrigued with this birth certificate issue, I'm going ask my vet if my dog, who happens to have a birth certificate listing him unsurprisingly as a dog, can have kittens if we just change his birth certificate to say "cat." Surely, the form must control practical reality.

Comment: Re the Holy Spirit, John 14.16f. has these words of Jesus (according to the NRSV, a translation which you may or may not consider inspired): "And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Advocate, to be with you forever. This is the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees him nor knows him. You know him, because he abides with you, and he will be with you." In Greek, "Spirit" is the neuter-gender "pneûma"; and the relative and personal pronouns translated here as "whom" and "him" are ALL in the neuter gender. (The two "he"s render no expressed pronoun.) In the Vulgate, "pneûma" is rendered by "spiritus," which is masculine-gender, so the pronouns should be understood to be masculine also.

The thing is, we English-speakers don't like to use "it" to refer to an active intelligent agent with whom we are supposed to feel sympathy. So though "it abides with you" is strictly accurate, we moderns tend not to be ready to accept it here.

Comment: Point by point:

1. Gun control proponents' interpretation of the Second Amendment must prevail at all costs.
2. Columbine had nothing to do with the issue of concealed carry.  Colorado's CHP laws are in line with 44 other states (either "shall issue" or "Constitutional Carry").
3. The silencer/suppressor bill may, indeed, return, and Congress will decide it's fate, as it should be.  As for other "NRA-desired perks," you'll have to be a little more specific.
4. Republicans and Democrats, alike, have a responsibility to address the shortcomings of our mental health system.  BOTH parties have failed in this regard.

Comment: Hey Hulali.  Those species you listed don't "infectiously spread" toxoplasma.  If they are infected, the parasite will either asexually multiply, cause disease and kill them or encyst in tissue and not result in disease symptoms.  If, and only if, they are eaten by something else (and not cooked) can they spread toxo and it would only be to the individual that consumed the cyst.  The cysts or protozoa die quickly when they are exposed to the environment when the animal dies and rots.  So for most larger mammals and animal in the Hawaii toxo runs into a dead end if it infects them.  Cats, who collectively shed billions of oocysts (eggs) into the environment can infect any bird or mammal that consumes it and each animal is differently susceptible to the disease.  Toxo may enter the marine ecosystem when there are sewage spills but that will depend on the level of treatment and if infected cat litter was flushed.  Humans don't shed toxo oocysts, so it doesn't matter if there is human poo

Comment: After a year they still can't speak the language?

My grandparents  immigrated from Holland after WW2  it took them about 6 months and their spelling and grammar puts mine to shame.

Sometimes the best help you can give people is to make them stand on their own two feet - ask any parent.

Comment: I will point out that the Nuclear Safety and Control Act (federal legislation) does grant authority to the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission to regulate and control the handling of radioactive material. So legislation does exist.  
But, I don't see the logic of allowing politicians and ignorant voting masses to govern a process for determining a safe solution to disposal of nuclear waste in Canada.  
Let me put it to you this way:  We can all agree that we should fix congenital heart defects in children.  But we don't ask voters to weigh in on how the procedure should be carried out.  We leave it to medical professionals, regulated by Health Canada.
In the same way, we all agree nuclear waste should be properly and safely disposed of.  But in this case, we feel technical expertise is not to be trusted, and only politicians and the ignorant masses can find the real solution.
Either you trust the experts or you don't.  You can't pick and choose your science.

Comment: As cities and suburbs try to cram more people into the city by building upwards, this is inevitable. Despite building more subways and having more buses, more people will inevitably mean more cars as people sometimes can't or won't take public transit. Take River District in Vancouver for example. An old industrial area, they are now building massive condos, cramming 30K people into that area. There is one bus route that barely comes in off peak times so you pretty much need a car to survive. The only restaurant is a burger joint.Want some milk? You will need to bike or walk up a huge hill 45 minutes each way. Yes, grocery stores will be coming in maybe 5 years but in the meantime, people still need to drive everywhere. Traffic just gets worse and people will always try to rush it. Perhaps we need to stop and think about just developing anywhere and everywhere. Cars aren't the only things that need to slow down. Development needs to slow down as well.

Comment: In my day, the view was that kids should learn keypunch skills.  Set them up for life, don't you know. Because punched cards were the future of computing.  

But we all know what happened to keypunch machines.  In ten years time, coding may also be obsolete what with voice recognition and improved computer interfaces.  

Moreover, Having every kid learn coding is like having every kid learn how bake or use a lathe or speak Spanish.  Sure, those are useful skills.  But it's not for everybody.  A kid can decide at a certain age if they want to pursue them.  But they don't all need it. Better we should focus on making sure they can read, write, and have basic math and science skills.

Comment: "they are coming to Canada as one of several choices that they could have made. "

Maybe, maybe not. Often the immigrants' only criteria is getting out of a third-world country and into a developed one, Canada may not be their first choice. 

Different countries have different criteria for accepting immigrants, and so Canada may in fact be a second or third choice. 

That is very different from the immigrant from a developed, western country making a choice to immigrate to a very specific other developed country, just as a Canadian may want to live in France, or Germany, or Japan. It is because they specifically want to live there, because they appreciate something about the country besides the standard of living.
