Comment: Not true.  Deficit spending depends on the saving preferences of the private sector and the current account balance.  Holding the external sector constant, If the private sector wishes to net save (and that is the long run tendency as people wish to save for retirement) then the government will have to run a deficit regardless of the state of the business cycle.  This tidy fiction of running in the red during recessions and in the black during expansions ignores the sectoral balances that underpin the spending/saving tendencies.  It's safe to say that everything you and most people contributing to this thread believe to be true is just not so.

Oh, and the debt-gdp ratio is meaningless when you are dealing with a country that issues its own currency.  It can never go bankrupt and can never run out of money.

Comment: I would argue there are well known issues with constituency voting, but I would favor the Van Zyl Slabbert proposal - which is to do, at parliamentary level - the same thing we currently do at municipal level - with half of the members being from party lists and half from constituency voting. This is enough to deprive a bad party of it's majority if it messes up, ensures every constituency has a voice in parliament representing specifically their interests, and it still removes much of the problems that made us shy away from it in the first place (like cultural island voting that ends up with a parliament that can't get anything done because no two PMs agree on anything).
As for direct democracy - some version of that should be brought in, if not the Swiss version than the California or Oregon versions perhaps -where any citizen can propose a law and, if it has enough support, it gets voted on and (subject to constitutionality) can become law if it passes.

Comment: Agreed.  PERA's investment returns aren't really the problem.  Basing benefits on an unrealistic 8% expected return was.

Allowing benefits to reach 80%, 90%, even 100% of highest average salary is wholly irresponsible. 60% is a more common private sector max. And more responsible. Allowing benefits to start as early as age 50 or 55 was equally as irresponsible. As was a whopping 3.5% annual COLA baked in regardless of inflation rate.

The people that retired during those years hit the jackpot. Can't blame them for the government being stupid and irresponsible, of course. But they've WAY over-benefitted, and now current employees and taxpayers are taking the hit for those irresponsible over-promises. 

Only now are these proposed changes getting closer to reality and sustainability.

"... et sacrificium Patriarchae nostri Abrahe, et quod tibi obtulit summus sacerdos tuus Melchisedech, sanctum sacrificium, immaculatam hostiam."

"...  the sacrifice of Abraham, our father in faith, and the offering of your high priest Melchizedek, a holy sacrifice, a spotless victim."

And there is a reason I listed easily accessibility as well as cost. Even if some forms of documentation might be free, they're also often gated behind limited locations, hours of operation, and transportation options. If the documentation is free but the office issuing then is only open two days a month, is several miles away and you're going to have to miss a day or work to get it and may not even have a car to get there then the documentation is neither "free" nor reasonably accessible.

Comment: Suppose that every day, ten men go down to the neighborhood pub for beer and the bill for all ten comes to $100. If they paid their bill the way we pay our income taxes in America, it would go something like this…
•	The first four men (the poorest) would pay nothing
•	The fifth would pay $1
•	The sixth would pay $3
•	The seventh would pay $7
•	The eighth would pay $12
•	The ninth would pay $18
•	The tenth man (the richest) would pay $59
So, that’s what they decided to do.
The ten men drank in the bar every day and seemed quite happy with the arrangement, until one day, the owner threw them a curve ball. “Since you’re all such good customers,” he said, “I’m going to reduce the cost of your daily beer by $20″.  Drinks for the ten men would now cost just $80.     

cont...........

Comment: I have no formal legal training or experience. However, I do find some fault in Mr. Schuman's arguments.
It appears that in Korematsu vs. United States, the "...the Supreme Court heard a challenge to the constitutionality of statutes..." The Executive Order 9066 itself was not challenged.
Then there's "...Nothing in the judicial or extra-judicial writings of any of the well-regarded judges —  indicates an ideological bias." Perhaps nothing in the writing of the judges indicated bias. However, the actions of the judges allow for that possibility. If the case is heard at a higher appellate level, we may know more. For now, absent the existence of certified mind readers (Mr. Spock, where are you when we really need you?) we really don't know about the judges motivations.

Comment: After repeatedly railing against professional athletes over what he misperceived as slights to the flag and military, Trump disparaged by joking Wednesday about a bugle call that is part of the armed forces’ time-honored tradition of showing respect for the Stars and Stripes.
The bugle call occurred during Trump’s interview with Fox's Hannity, conducted in a hangar used by the Pennsylvania Air National Guard.
“What a nice sound that is. Are they playing that for you or for me?” Trump said smarmingly, before turning to the audience. “They’re playing that in honor of his ratings”
The bugle call was “Retreat,” which signifies the lowering of the American flag on a military installation.
Although Trump attended a military high school, and wraps himself in the flag,remained unmoving and unaware of the music’s meaning.

Comment: You are right Jabberwocky. And the fact is that most large account holders have exactly that arrangement.
All of my clients with larger than $500,000 accounts pay my firm .8% of assets per year. I receive 75% or .6% of that amount. My compensation is not impacted by what investment choices are made.
Smaller sized clients are in "client name"  accounts that will typically have 1% (gross) trailer commissions paid.

Comment: Beautiful poignant article. Katrina, my heart aches for you. I know that the "what if" cycle can consume loved ones of those who have passed. I hope that through the trying times you can remember that accidents happen and not feel guilty. Instead of what if, try to remember that you were a wonderful amazing mother to Jack every day. It sounds like he lived a joyful life thanks to you, Jack's family and friends.

Comment: You are absolutely/mostly correct.  We do not have the rutting issues in Fairbanks that you have in Anchorage.  Granted the Glenn highway sees far more traffic that we do but our roads last far longer.  The reason is the aggregate.  We have a much harder aggregate in the interior so our roads do not wear as much.  The Johanson expressway made it 20 years without resurfacing.  I'd say that has a lot more to do with whats underneath than what is rolling on top.

Comment: Data from the U.S. shows that the fuel efficiency of new vehicle purchases and discretionary driving levels are both sensitive to the price of fuel.

Because Americans now hold on to new vehicles for an average of 6.5 years the overall national fuel efficiency is slow to change, and there are economic disincentives to trading in a vehicle once it's been purchased even if fuel prices rise.

Comment: Bill, you are entitled to your "not true" opinion as much as I am to mine. But the "lefties" you complain about are not president of the U.S.A. I hold my president to the highest possible standard, and I would hope that you do too; and that we all do. What somebody else does or doesn't do is irrelevant. It's "whataboutism" that is misdirection, essentially, trying to justify the unfitness for office of the current president by saying what about so-and-so, as if somebody else's failings justify the president's. Not that I agree with your opinion on "lefties;"  but the issue is the president's unfitness for office. "Lefties" are irrelevant.
